Award.AwardTitle: Revealing the Inside of a Nanoscale Na-ion Battery: New Understanding on Sodium Intercalation in Cathodes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to advance the understanding of the underlying mechanisms that are active in Na-ion reactions in electrodes and chemically-induced failure and fracture in Na-ion batteries. For this purpose, the cathode electrode will be subjected to electrochemical probing inside a transmission electron microscope (TEM) where the microstructure of electrodes can be simultaneously monitored in high resolution. Room-temperature rechargeable Na-ion batteries can be competitive to Li-ion batteries due to their lower cost and the widespread availability of the sodium resources. While tremendous research is focused on Li-ion batteries worldwide, scientific challenges associated with room-temperature rechargeable sodium-ion batteries have been relatively unexplored. This is of prime importance considering that Li resources are very limited and their price has increased continuously during the past 20 years. The challenges of Na-ion batteries are much more complicated than the Li-ion case, as Na-ions are larger than Li-ions by 70 percent, which induces large mechanical stresses upon driving the Na-ions into the host electrode. The entry of sodium into the electrodes triggers complicated chemical reactions and failures that are poorly understood, and the battery life is reduced drastically.

An important challenge in the broad use of Na-ion batteries is the very low cycling stability in service conditions. Through this grant, the PI will investigate several unresolved scientific challenges in new cathode materials which, if successfully resolved, could enable the commercialization of long lasting rechargeable Na-ion battery technologies. Several venues for integrating research with undergraduate education and outreach activities are proposed. Female and minority students for undergraduate education will be exposed to this research project through simple introductions to the battery subject. Other outreach activities are also planned for local high school female and underrepresented students. Real time videos of microscopy experiments will be produced and made available to the community via YouTubeÂ© and selected scientific networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New battery materials are needed to reduce the cost of energy storage. While there have been many candidate materials to replace lithium ion batteries, very few electrodes have been identified for Na-ion storage. According to several national reports by National Science Foundation and Department of Energy, real-time visualization and chemical probing of battery dynamics play a significant role in identifying the underlying mechanisms responsible for battery failure. In-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) diagnostics such as the one employed by our group shed lights to mechanisms that sodium ions transport in electrodes by tracking the structural evolutions during the electrochemical reactions. In our review paper in Nature Communications, we have been able to envision future directions to study electrochemistry challenges in battery materials. Our contribution will help to design low cost, safe, and high-energy Na-ion battery materials.

Under this award, 19 journal articles was published in highly respected journals such as Nature Communications, ACS Nano, Nano Letters, Advanced Energy Materials, Nano Energy, Journal of Electrochemical Society, Chemistry of Materials, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, Advanced Functional Materials, and others. We also presented our research results in more than 30 conferences. We were also interviewed by several news outlets, web media and professional society about our contributions to the field of energy storage.

In addition, the PI developed a new graduate course titled ME594-Energy Storage to teach students about the latest progress and challenges in the field of energy storage including sodium-ion batteries. More than 40 graduate students registered for this course and visited the PI's lab on battery manufacturing and materials synthesis. More than 5 PhD students and postdocs benefited from this award by working with one of the state-of-the-art in situ aberration-corrected STEM/TEM systems for electrochemical analysis. These training were critical in their job placements and subsequent research. One PhD student is now hired by Argonne National Lab to continue doing in situ TEM for energy storage materials. One of the postdocs is now a professor at Shanghai University in China and is working on energy storage field. Another PhD student was hired by a semiconductor company at California. Several collaboration programs were established with energy storage scientists at Argonne National Laboratory, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, University of Bath in UK, University of Maryland in College Park, and others. These research communications resulted in several journal articles. Three undergraduate students conducted research at the PI laboratory and were trained on various aspects of energy storage including coin cell fabrication, electrochemical testing of batteries, battery electrode fabrication for cathodes and anodes, and materials characterization such as Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction.

Our work has opened new opportunities to utilize two-dimensional (2D) phosphorene materials as sodium electrode materials with possibility to charge or discharge at very high rates. In our work on phosphorene sodiation, we presented a new experimental study of sodium ion transport in few layer and monolayer phosphorene by using state-of-the-art-in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Our atomic scale observation reveals a highly anisotropic diffusion pathway for sodium ions transport in phosphorene. We observed that sodium ions prefer to diffuse along the [100] direction in phosphorene. The DFT calculation was also used to explore the diffusivity of sodium ions in phosphorene and gain an insight into the effect of surface and the edge sites on the transport properties of phosphorene. Our results showed a two-stage sodiation mechanism in black phosphorous. Upon sodium intercalation, the stacking order of black phosphorous changes from AB to AC. Subsequently, we observed amorphous stripes formed in BP during sodiation process. This phenomenon was attributed to the lattice constrain of BP. The sodium intercalation or other metal intercalation not only induces structural evolution but also modulates the electronic structure, such as carrier type. This suggests new opportunities to exploit alloyed phosphorene for nanoelectronic applications.
